description: Part 3 of Flashcards Set 2 (Policy provisions, group & health insurance basics)

questions.question: A Limited-Pay Life policy has
options: premium payments limited to a specified number of years
premium payments that are paid to age 100
questions.explanation: In a Limited-Pay Life policy, premium payments are limited to a specified number of years.

questions.question: What type of life insurance gives the greatest amount of coverage for a limited period of time?
questions.explanation: Term insurance would provide the greatest amount of protection for a limited period of time.

questions.question: What type of life policy covers 2 lives and pays the face amount after the first one dies?
questions.explanation: A policy that promises to pay the face amount on the death of first of 2 lives covered by the policy is called a Joint Life Policy.

questions.question: How does a typical Variable Life Policy investment account grow?
options: Based on returns from insurer's general account
questions.explanation: A Variable Life Policy has investment values based instruments such as mutual funds, stocks, and bonds.

questions.question: All of these insurance products require an agent to have proper FINRA securities registration in order to sell them EXCEPT for
questions.explanation: An agent must have proper FINRA securities registration to sell all of these products EXCEPT Modified Whole Life.

questions.question: K buys a policy where the premium stays fixed for the first 5 years. The premium then increases in year 6 and stays level thereafter, all the while the death benefit remains the same. What kind of policy is this?
questions.explanation: The type of policy in this situation is a Modified Whole Life.

questions.question: A 15-year mortgage is best protected by what kind of life policy?
questions.explanation: A 15-year mortgage is best protected by a 15-year decreasing term policy.

questions.question: A father who dies within 3 years after purchasing a life insurance policy on his infant daughter can have the policy premiums waived under which provision?
questions.explanation: A payor provision provides that in the event of death or disability of the adult premium payor, the premiums on a juvenile policy will be waived until the insured child reaches a specified age or the maturity date of the contract.

questions.question: D needs life insurance that provides coverage for only a limited amount of time while also paying the lowest possible premium. What kind of policy is needed?
questions.explanation: Life insurance written to cover a need for a specified period of time at the lowest premium is called level term insurance.

questions.question: When is the face amount paid under a Joint Life and Survivor policy?
options: upon death of the first insured
upon death of the last insured
when one of the insureds becomes disabled and no longer able to make premium payments
questions.explanation: A Joint Life and Survivor policy pays benefits after the death of the last insured.

questions.question: Which of these characteristics is consistent with a Straight Life policy?
options: Owner can adjust both premium and death benefit
Premiums are lower for the first five years, increase the sixth year, then levels off for the remaining length of the contract
Owner has the option of converting to term insurance
Premiums are payable for as long as there is insurance coverage in force
questions.explanation: Straight whole life provides permanent level protection with level premiums from the time the policy is issued until the insured's death (or age 100).

questions.question: Which statement is true concerning a Variable Universal Life policy?
options: Policyowner controls where the investment will go and selects the amount of the premium payment
Policyowner has no say where the investment will go but can choose the premium mode
The investment vehicle for this type of policy is held in the insurer's general portfolio
The death benefit can vary but the policyowner has no say in the premium amount paid
questions.explanation: With Variable Universal Life, the policyowner controls the investment of cash values and selects the timing and amount of premium payments.

questions.question: Which of these is considered a statement that is assured to be true in every respect?
questions.explanation: A warranty is a statement that is considered guaranteed to be true.

questions.question: Insurance policies offered on a "take it or leave it" basis are considered what?
questions.explanation: Because insurance policies are offered on a "take it or leave it" basis they are referred to as Contracts of Adhesion.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT considered to be an element of an insurance contract?
questions.explanation: The elements of an insurance contract do not include negotiating.

questions.question: Who makes the legally enforceable promises in a unilateral contract?
questions.explanation: Under a unilateral insurance policy, the insurance company makes the legally enforceable promises.

questions.question: A Business Overhead Expense policy would cover which of the following if a business owner becomes disabled?
questions.explanation: A Business Overhead Expense policy is designed to cover certain overhead expenses (rent, taxes, utility bills, employee's salaries etc) that continue when the business owner is disabled.

questions.question: Which statement is TRUE regarding a group accident & health policy issued to an employer?
options: Neither the employer or employee are policyowners
The employer is issued a certificate of coverage and each employee receives a policy
The employer is the policyowner and each employee receives a certificate of coverage
Both the employer and employee are policyowners
questions.explanation: With a group accident and health plan, a master policy is issued to the employer and each employee receives a certificate of insurance.

questions.question: Many small business owners worry how their business would survive financially if the owner becomes disabled. The policy which BEST addresses this concern is
questions.explanation: A Business Overhead Expense policy's purpose is to cover certain overhead expenses that continue when the businessowner is disabled.

questions.question: J has an Accidental Death and Dismemberment policy with a principal sum of $50,000. While trimming the hedges, J cuts off one of his fingers. What is the MAXIMUM J will receive from his policy?
questions.explanation: The maximum sum payable would be the capital sum, or $25,000.
